content.text: Integration is the inverse operation of differentiation. While derivatives measure the rate of change, integrals help us find the area under curves and accumulate quantities over time or space.
An antiderivative of a function f(x) is a function F(x) whose derivative is f(x). In other words, if F'(x) = f(x), then F(x) is an antiderivative of f(x).

# Example: If f(x) = 2x, then F(x) = x² + C is an antiderivative
# because d/dx(x² + C) = 2x

# The general form of an indefinite integral:
# ∫ f(x) dx = F(x) + C
# where C is the constant of integration

items: Indefinite Integral: ∫ f(x) dx = F(x) + C, represents a family of functions
Definite Integral: ∫[a to b] f(x) dx = F(b) - F(a), gives a specific numerical value
Fundamental Theorem of Calculus: Links differentiation and integration

content.text: Key takeaway: Integration is the reverse of differentiation. Indefinite integrals include a constant of integration, while definite integrals evaluate to specific values.
Just as there are rules for differentiation, there are corresponding rules for integration. These basic formulas form the foundation for solving more complex integrals.

# Power Rule for Integration:
# ∫ x^n dx = (x^(n+1))/(n+1) + C, where n ≠ -1

# Examples:
# ∫ x³ dx = x⁴/4 + C
# ∫ x^(-2) dx = -1/x + C
# ∫ √x dx = ∫ x^(1/2) dx = (2/3)x^(3/2) + C

items: Trigonometric: ∫ sin(x) dx = -cos(x) + C, ∫ cos(x) dx = sin(x) + C

content.text: Key takeaway: Master these basic integration rules as they are the building blocks for more advanced integration techniques.
The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus connects differentiation and integration, showing that they are inverse operations. It provides a practical way to evaluate definite integrals.

# Fundamental Theorem of Calculus:
# If F(x) is an antiderivative of f(x), then:
# ∫[a to b] f(x) dx = F(b) - F(a)

# Example: Evaluate ∫[1 to 3] 2x dx
# Step 1: Find antiderivative: F(x) = x²
# Step 2: Apply theorem: F(3) - F(1) = 9 - 1 = 8

items: Geometric Interpretation: Definite integrals represent the signed area under a curve
Properties: ∫[a to a] f(x) dx = 0, ∫[a to b] f(x) dx = -∫[b to a] f(x) dx
Additivity: ∫[a to c] f(x) dx = ∫[a to b] f(x) dx + ∫[b to c] f(x) dx

content.text: Key takeaway: Definite integrals give exact numerical values and represent the net area between the curve and the x-axis over a given interval.
